Name: breast_cancer_sklearn_classification
Title: Breast Cancer Classification using Sklearn Datasets
Short Hypothesis: A simple ML model (Logistic Regression, RandomForest) trained on the sklearn breast cancer dataset can achieve high classification accuracy.
Related Work: This is a standard benchmark (toy dataset) in machine learning. Baseline accuracy is known to be high, making it a good test for the agent's ability to execute code, improve models (scaling), and explore alternatives (RandomForest).
Abstract: This research aims to test the AI Scientist's capability on a simple, self-contained task. The model will use `sklearn.datasets.load_breast_cancer()` to load data, preprocess it (scaling), and compare different classification models (LogisticRegression, RandomForest) to maximize accuracy and F1-score.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1. The dataset is very simple, and results may not generalize to complex, real-world problems.
2. If llama3:70b fails to follow instructions, manual prompt simplification (Radical Fix) might be needed in parallel_agent.py.
description: Develop a machine learning model to classify tumors as malignant or benign using the built-in breast cancer dataset from scikit-learn. The implementation must use `sklearn.datasets.load_breast_cancer()` to load data and `sklearn.model_selection.train_test_split` for splitting. The goal is to achieve the highest possible accuracy.
data_description: The dataset will be loaded directly from `sklearn.datasets.load_breast_cancer()`. No external CSV files are required. Features are numeric, and the target is binary (0 or 1).

evaluation_metrics.description: The percentage of correctly classified tumors (higher is better).
The harmonic mean of precision and recall for the positive class (higher is better).

stages.description: Implement a baseline solution using `LogisticRegression` with default parameters. Ensure data is split into training and testing sets. Report the test Accuracy and F1-Score.
Improve the baseline by applying `StandardScaler` to the data before fitting the `LogisticRegression` model, as logistic regression benefits from feature scaling. Report the new scores.
Implement and evaluate an alternative, tree-based model, such as `RandomForestClassifier`, to see if it outperforms the scaled logistic regression. Report its scores.
Tune the hyperparameters of the `RandomForestClassifier` (e.g., `n_estimators`, `max_depth`) using `GridSearchCV` to find the optimal settings and report the final best accuracy.
